title: Oilzum sign from 50's or 60's
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724115041im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Oilzum%20003323_3701.jpg)

Totally stumped as to what font this is, have looked for days online with no luck, any help would be appreciated, cheers
author: Sasaf

comments.content:
Interesting. I spent some time trying to track this down.  
Oilzum has been around as a product for well over a century. The design of the central logo seems to be pre WWI.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724115041im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OilzumFullSign_4244.jpg)
  
Here is all of the lettering that encircles the logo.  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724115041im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OilzumLettering_5789.jpg)
  
I am have not determined when the lettering was added to the logo to make the Oilzum sign, other than it was some time in the first half of the 20th century.  
The style is thick and thin sans, developed from the 1890s onward in fonts such as Taylor Gothic, Studley and Globe Gothic. It is found in only a few American typefaces from the 20th century.  
I checked my file collection and did not find a match.  
Pending a check of McGrew's American Metal Typefaces, I suggest that this is well executed hand lettering with the flavor of the three mentioned fonts.  
Don

Thank you Don for taking the time to look into it, I think it's a really nice looking font and being done by hand is really well done. There were some close matches out there but most were serif fonts and the w was always wrong. I'll have a look at those fonts you mentioned.

You're welcome. Also check out Middleton's Radiant.  
Don
